Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Wireless Power Transmission Architecture for Devices Implanted in Human Bodies

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to verify a distributed power transmission architecture to deliver radio frequency power to devices implanted in human bodies. The proposed architecture aims to construct efficient and reliable wireless channels in complex in-body environments for power transfer. If proved feasible, it would fundamentally resolve a few problems associated with the state-of-the-art wireless charging technologies, including low efficiency, potential hazard to human health, and large and heavy apparatuses.

The intellectual merit is the proposed distributed power transmission architecture, which is potentially transformative to enable next-generation systems for wireless power delivery. Specifically, it has two major innovations. First, radio frequency power is transmitted via multiple antenna elements physically attached to a large area of skin and electrically matched to the skin. Second, the multiple antenna elements jointly behave as a retro-reflective beamformer: guided by the pilot signal sent from an implanted device, their radiations spatially converge to the target device with power intensities at all other locations below safety levels regulated for human.

The broader impacts include (i) promoting the contemporary Body Area Networks to the next level of integration; (ii) supporting both graduate and undergraduate students and provide them with excellent research opportunities; (iii) making constructive impacts to the science and engineering curricula at the three participating institutes; (iv) offering local high school students and teachers to participate in the proposed research activities; and (v) impacting both research and educational aspects of North Texas' high-tech industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF funded project investigated a distributed power transmission architecture to deliver radio frequency power to devices implanted in human bodies. The architecture constructed efficient and reliable wireless channels in complex in-body environments for power transfer and fundamentally resolved a few challenging problems associated with wireless charging technologies, including low efficiency, potential hazard to human health and large and heavy apparatuses.

The distributed power transmission architecture has two major innovations. First, the radio frequency power is transmitted via multiple antenna elements physically attached to a large area of skin and electrically matched to the skin. Second, the multiple antenna elements jointly behave as a retro-reflective beamformer: guided by the pilot signal sent from an implanted device, their radiations spatially converge to the target device with power intensities at all other locations below safety levels regulated for human.

In addition to radio frequency energy harvesting, energy harvesting from body motion has also been investigated. A self-powering mechanism for a synchronized switch harvesting on inductor (SSHI) circuit in series connections have been investigated to harvest vibration energy from multiple piezoelectric oscillators. The self-powered SSHI circuit is designed to perform an AC to DC conversion without displacement sensors and switch controllers, which is highly desired in practical energy harvesting applications.

To demonstrate the proposed energy harvesting approaches, throughout this project several innovative integrated circuit structures, including a compact and low-cost retro-reflective beamforming circuit, an energy-efficient and speed-enhanced successive approximation (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC), and a highly linear and ultra-low noise broadband low noise amplifier (LNA) have been developed. These circuits also find a variety of applications in Internet of Things (IoT) sensing, micro sensor and sensor networks, and biomedical systems.

This NSF funded project helped to promote the wearable wireless body area networks and the emerging smart IoT sensors.  The project supported both graduate and undergraduate students and provided them with excellent research opportunities. Two PhD students are trained throughout this project. The project also supported undergraduate electrical engineering students carrying out a senior design project developing an electrocardiography (EKG) sensing and wireless charging and data transmission system. The project also made constructive impacts to the science and engineering curricula and the research and educational development of Texas' high-tech industries.


Last Modified: 02/05/2018
Modified by: Jinghong Chen

The architecture constructed efficient and reliable wireless channels in complex in-body environments for power transfer and fundamentally resolved a few challenging problems associated with wireless charging technologies, including low efficiency, potential hazard to human health and large and heavy apparatuses. First, the radio frequency power is transmitted via multiple antenna elements physically attached to a large area of skin and electrically matched to the skin. Second, the multiple antenna elements jointly behave as a retro-reflective beamformer: guided by the pilot signal sent from an implanted device, their radiations spatially converge to the target device with power intensities at all other locations below safety levels regulated for human. In addition to radio frequency energy harvesting, energy harvesting from body motion has also been investigated. A self-powering mechanism for a synchronized switch harvesting on inductor (SSHI) circuit in series connections have been investigated to harvest vibration energy from multiple piezoelectric oscillators. The self-powered SSHI circuit is designed to perform an AC to DC conversion without displacement sensors and switch controllers, which is highly desired in practical energy harvesting applications. To demonstrate the proposed energy harvesting approaches, throughout this project several innovative integrated circuit structures, including a compact and low-cost retro-reflective beamforming circuit, an energy-efficient and speed-enhanced successive approximation (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC), and a highly linear and ultra-low noise broadband low noise amplifier (LNA) have been developed. This NSF funded project helped to promote the wearable wireless body area networks and the emerging smart IoT sensors. The project supported both graduate and undergraduate students and provided them with excellent research opportunities. Two PhD students are trained throughout this project. The project also supported undergraduate electrical engineering students carrying out a senior design project developing an electrocardiography (EKG) sensing and wireless charging and data transmission system. The project also made constructive impacts to the science and engineering curricula and the research and educational development of Texas' high-tech industries.
